text: Here's your news update from KFIR's 720 AM, The Waste of the Valley.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The ACLU of Oregon filed suit Tuesday against the Medford Police Department, claiming it has illegally been compiling secret files on individuals and groups who protested against the Minneapolis police murder of George Floyd, who pushed for LGBTQ rights, who criticized the U.S.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Supreme Court's overturning of Roe v. Wade, and who advocated for homeless people and drug users.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Although the ACLU seemed to take a backseat as citizens discovered Oregon's government officials in the Secretary of State's and Governor's office were secretly collecting and helping to punish certain people on social media.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: People who were primarily conservative that were just speaking their mind.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Called Miss Dis and Mal Information, or MDM, they contracted with a British company to monitor law-abiding Oregonians.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But according to Oregon Live, this suit alleges that the Southern Oregon Police Department monitored social media accounts and combed news stories to build files against individuals and groups when they weren't suspected of any criminal activity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Filed in Jackson County, the lawsuit states that, simply put, MPD is abusing its power to spy on activists whose views it dislikes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And, not only that, building and maintaining files about such people and organizations without any justifiable law enforcement purpose.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: a blatant violation of Oregon law.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But city attorney Eric Mitten refuted the lawsuit's claim, saying in a written statement Tuesday that the police aren't judging individuals' political, religious, or social views as the department keeps tabs on various groups.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: He said they review publicly available social media over safety concerns related to public rallies and protests.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Police Chief Justin Ivins added, This ensures our ability to address potential safety concerns while safeguarding those exercising their constitutional right to free speech.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is Carla Davenport for KFI News, 720 AM, The Voice of the Valley.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: 70% of Oregon's wildfires are started by people.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: One careless spark can destroy all that we love.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It doesn't take much for a wildfire to ignite and spread quickly across our state's beautiful landscape.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Everyday activities like mowing your grass or driving your car can spark a wildfire.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Be extra careful this summer.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Check weather conditions, follow posted fire restrictions, and keep fire tools on hand to be able to extinguish sparks or fires quickly.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Go to KeepOregonGreen.org to learn how you can prevent wildfires.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Sponsored by the Keep Oregon Green Association, the Oregon Association of Broadcasters, and this station.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Here's a news update from KFIR's 720 AM, The Voice of the Valley.

text: As EV maker Elon Musk eyes a potential spot on Trump's White House, Trump announces that he'll rescind taxpayer-funded EV subsidies.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: As EV sales remain soft and not so appealing to consumers, especially with recent performance issues.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: In fact, this week...
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Ford Motor is canceling plans for a large electric sport utility vehicle and expects to take $2 billion in related special charges and write-downs as automakers continue adjusting their EV plans because of softer-than-expected demand.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The Dearborn, Michigan automaker this spring said it would delay plans for an electric three-row SUV by two years to a 2027 release date.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But that proposed delay didn't last.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: On Wednesday this week, the company said it is scrapping the model altogether, citing tough pricing pressures.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is Carla Davenport for KFI News, 720 AM, the Roots of the Valley.

text: At Hot Shot Secret, we share the science behind common diesel problems and their solutions.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: For example, diesel fuel C-Tain levels.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: In many states, the C-Tain rating in diesel fuel is 42 to 45.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Most diesel engines operate more efficiently with a C-Tain rating of 48 to 50.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: One treatment of Hot Shot Secret Diesel Extreme will raise your C-Tain seven points, increase fuel economy, and improve cold starts.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Due to a cleaner burn,
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: There are less hydrocarbons and particulate matter in your exhaust.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: This reduces the blockage of your diesel particulate filter.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Using Diesel Extreme generates 83% less DPF regenerations.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: The 6-in-1 Diesel Extreme formula also includes the most concentrated detergent on the market, lubricity enhancer, water demulsifier, rust and corrosion inhibitors, and a fuel stabilizer.
speaker: SPEAKER_10

text: Hot Shot Secret Diesel Extreme is available nationwide at truck stops, fine farm and auto stores, and online at hotshotsecret.com.

text: Have you seen how expensive new mattresses are?
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Well, five years ago, my wife, Carla Davenport, and I had just moved into a new place and the mattress that we had was, well, getting on in years.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: But we really did not want to invest in a whole new mattress as expensive as they were then.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And that was before Joe Biden.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: We kept seeing the MyPillow ads about his mattress topper.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And we thought, well, why not give that a try?
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: $250 was a lot cheaper than the $1,500 or more we were seeing for some mattresses.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: I have to say, after putting that mattress topper on, not only did it save us all that money, but it was the most comfortable mattress we'd ever slept on.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And we still have not replaced the mattress.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Right now, if you go to MyPillow.com forward slash KFIR, those mattress toppers are as low as $99.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: The 2.0 version, with its nano coils for even cooler sleep, is $229.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Save $160.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: The country's only elections group that forecasts legislative elections is predicting a 39 to 21 Democrat majority in Oregon's House and an 18 to 11 split in the state Senate.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Those margins would give Democrat leaders a supermajority to try to negotiate a new transportation funding package during the 2025 session, as any attempts to create new taxes or raise existing ones and without voter approval requires the supermajority.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that would likely bring about tolling and carbon taxing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The forecasting group only considers two of the state Senate races to be competitive, the 5th District along the Central Coast and the 25th District in East Multnomah County.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: There are no toss-ups in the House model, with the four closest predicted races tilting toward Democrats.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is Carla Davenport for KFI News, 720 AM, The Voice of the Valley.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_00
